title: Introduction to Robot Design
description: The course covers introduction to robots in different industries, microcontroller unit, programming using Arduino, sensors, actuators, mechanisms and engineering design principles. It provides the students extensive hands-on training on robot prototype development and experimental evaluation. It adopts a project-based learning approach: the students are required to design and build a fully functional robotic system that must be able to perform a specific task. Both mechanical and electronic hardware will be designed and developed by the students. The lectures and laboratory sessions are designed so as to equip them with the essential knowledge to successfully complete their project.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: (1) be able to program embedded micro-controllers for processing input/output digital and analog signals; (2) be able to select the appropriate sensors and instrument a robot for processing the environment’s sensory data; (3) be able to perform computer-aided designs (CAD) of mechanical components and select appropriate materials for a specific application; (4) be able to select actuators and the motion driving mechanisms for a given engineering requirement; (5) be able to implement simple control laws for conducting a specified motion task on the robot; (6) be able to design, implement, conduct, and evaluate experiments.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: (1) Arduino Programming Notebook. B. Evans, 1st edition, 2007 (2) Autonomous Mobile Robots. R. Siegwart and I.R. Nourbakhsh, MIT Press, 2004  (3) Red G. Martin, Robotic Explorations: A Hands-on Introduction to Engineering, Prentice Hall, 2001

title: Computational Design and Fabrication
requirements: Not for students who have taken MAEG2010.
description: This course introduces engineering design fundamentals, manufacturing, and practical use of advanced computer-aided design software and prototyping techniques. The topics include engineering graphics, geometric dimensioning and tolerances, working drawings, conventional manufacturing, reverse engineering, digital manufacturing (CNC), additive manufacturing, and micromachining.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: (1) be able to read and understand mechanical drawings and CAD models of existing design;  (2) be proficient in using CAD software for product modelling, drafting, and analysis;  (3) have basic knowledge and exposure to product design and state-of-the-art manufacturing process; (4) be able to carry out simple product design and 3-D prototyping in a team.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: (1) Gary R. Bertoline, Introduction to Graphics Communications for Engineers, McGraw Hill, 2009 (2) Benhabib, Beno. Manufacturing: design, production, automation, and integration. CRC Press, 2003. (3) Raja, Vinesh, and Kiran J. Fernandes, eds. Reverse engineering: an industrial perspective. Springer Science & Business Media, 2007.

title: Computer-aided Drafting
requirements: Not for students who have taken MAEG1020.
description: The course introduces the basics of engineering graphics, background of computer-aided design, views and projections, sections and cutting planes, dimensioning, tolerances, working drawings, and basic guidelines in product design. It provides a series of homework and a project for students to learn and practice using standard CAD packages for creating 2D engineering drawing, 3D models, animation and analysis.

title: Engineering Mechanics
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR2400.
description: This course provides an introduction to the statics and dynamics. You will be introduced to and become familiar with all relevant physical properties and fundamental laws governing the behavior of particles and rigid bodies, and you will learn how to solve a variety of problems in terms of kinematics, kinetics, energy, and momentum of particles and rigid bodies. The emphasis is on the physical understanding of why particles or rigid bodies behave the way they do in both the statics and the dynamics.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: (1) be able to understand the basic principles of engineering mechanics including both statics and dynamics; (2) be able to interpret, simplify, and model given engineering problem situations; (3) be able to work as individuals to conduct his/her engineering analysis through written descriptions or by oral presentation in a professional manner; (4) be able to apply the fundamentals of mechanics to the preliminary design and evaluation of mechanical systems; (5) be able to understand the mathematical models used for analysis and design; (6) be able to apply the basic principles of particle and rigid body kinematics and dynamic analysis; (7) be able to use different methods of approaching dynamics problems, such as work and energy, and impulse and momentum.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: (1) R. C. Hibbeler, et al. Engineering Mechanics Statics in SI unit, 14th Edition, 2009. (2) R. C. Hibbeler, et al. Engineering Mechanics Dynamics in SI unit, 14th Edition, 2009. (3) F. P. Beer et al. Vector Mechanics for Engineers: Statics, 9th Edition, 2009. (4) F. P. Beer et al. Vector Mechanics for Engineers: Dynamics, 9th Edition, 2009. (5) James L. Meriam, L. G. Kraige, J. N. Bolton, Engineering Mechanics: Statics, 8th Edition, Wiley (6) James L. Meriam, L. G. Kraige, J. N. Bolton, Engineering Mechanics: Dynamics, 8th Edition, Wiley

title: Thermodynamics
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR2402.
description: This course will cover fundamental topics in thermodynamics including basic concepts, heat and work, pure substance, ideal gas, first law and second law of thermodynamics, entropy, gas and vapor power cycles, and refrigeration cycles.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: (1) understand the fundamental concepts and principles in thermodynamics; (2) analyze and interpret experimental results in the scope of thermodynamics; (3) utilize the techniques to solve various thermodynamic problems; (4) apply the knowledge learned in this course in daily and engineering applications.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: Yunus A. Cengel and Michael A. Boles, Thermodynamics, An Engineering Approach, 8th Edition in SI units, McGraw-Hill.

title: Robot Development in Practice: From Design to Prototyping
description: This course is aimed to enhance students' professional and engineering interests through practicum and team-based development of practical robots through participation in hands-on competitions. This is a project-based experiential course that exposes students to design and build practical robots. Students will be required to conceptualize and perform high-level design of a robot system, and then design and build various components using skills including CAD drawing, mechanical structure, electronic circuits and programming skills. Students will practice their engineering knowledge through tutorial-style workshops and laboratory sessions. The goal is to develop and nurture skills in problem-solving, hands-on skills, project and time management through the project. Students should obtain approval from the course instructor to ensure that the participated activities are in-line with the course learning outcomes.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: (1) acquire basic mechanical, electronic and programming knowledge in the development of robots; (2) be able to use motors, pneumatic actuator and sensors; (3) be able to apply CAD drawing and manufacturing knowledge; (4) have hands-on experience in robotic design and problem solving skills; (5) solve robot design problems in a team environment and practicing of project management.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
required_readings: The details will be provided by the course instructor.

title: Technology, Society and Engineering Practice
requirements: Not for students who have taken ENGG2601.
description: This course introduces basic and fundamental knowledge in technology, engineering, and their impacts on human society. Important and various aspects of engineering will be introduced, like engineering design and innovation, engineering project management, and intellectual property. Student have opportunities to participate some field study to have a better understanding of engineering design, innovation, and industrial manufacturing in practice. This course also provides several seminars given by real engineers with topics on current engineering issues, career decision-making strategies, and opinions such as internships and life-long study.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: (1) examine the impact of engineering and technology on the society and the environment;  (2) recognize the contributions of engineers to the society;  (3) appreciate the design and innovation aspects of engineering profession; (4) acquire the skills and tools to manage engineering projects; (5) learn the communication and presentation skills for working in a team; (6) understand the value of being an ethical engineer and a responsible citizen.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: (1) E.A. Stephan et al., Thinking like an engineer: an active learning approach, Pearson Prentice Hall, 2011. (2) A. Shtub et al., Project management: processes, methodologies, and economics, 2nd edition, Pearson Prentice Hall, 2005.

title: Engineering Practicum
requirements: Not for students who have taken ENGG2602.
description: The course combines activities designed to develop employability with the knowledge and skills gained through attending workshops or seminars. Successful completion of the course will provide students with the employability skills required for transition to the world of work. Students who have attended certain industrial and professional workshops or seminars required by the MAEG programme may be able to count these towards the course.

title: Prototypes to Products
description: This course covers the fundamental ideas and concepts of product engineering processes from a prototype to product. Students learn about creativity and product engineering principles through both lectures and practical projects. Topics include opportunity identification; idea generation; survey of customers and markets; devising concepts and building models and drawings; building and testing mockups; project management; and construction of a high quality prototype. We encourage students to form teams and enroll together.

title: Mechanics of Materials
description: This course is a study of mechanics of materials. It covers the following topics: linear elasticity, stress and strain, stress-strain relations, loading and deformation, statically indeterminate problems, torsion, shear forces and bending moments, stresses in beams, deflection of beams, stresses in thin-walled pressure vessels, column and buckling.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: (1) understand the fundamental concepts of material properties; (2) understand how to extend equilibrium analysis to deformable bodies; (3) be able to analyze and interpret experimental results related to the properties of materials; (4) be able to familiar with the techniques to solve mechanics of materials problem; (5) be able to evaluate the mechanical properties of materials in daily and engineering applications.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: (1) Mechanics of Materials, by F. P. Beer, E. R. Johnston, Jr., and J. T. DeWolf, 7th ed., McGraw-Hill, 2018.  (2) Mechanics of Materials, by J. M. Gere and B. J. Goodno, Brief Edition, Cengage Learning, 2011.

title: Manufacturing Technology
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR3404.
description: This course provides students with fundamental background of manufacturing technologies. It covers the following topics: overview of manufacturing technologies, engineering materials, metal forming processes, plastic forming processes, 3D printing processes, machining processes, micro-manufacturing and fabrication. A number of industrial visits and hands-on labs are also included.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: (1) understand the core technologies of manufacturing, their features, benefits and limitations; (2) be skilled at communicating with appropriate media, including written reports and oral presentations on the core technologies of manufacturing; (3) understand the important aspects of manufacturing by applying IT technologies; (4) understand the influences of technological, environmental, social and cultural considerations on design and manufacturing decisions.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: S. Kalpakjian and S. R. Schmid, Manufacturing Engineering and Technology, 5th edition, Pearson Education (Prentice Hall), 2006.

title: Fluid Mechanics
description: This course covers important topics in fluid mechanics. It will introduce the nature of fluids; pressure, hydrostatics, and buoyancy; integral and differential equations of fluid flows; conservation of mass, momentum, and energy; basic mass transfer; inviscid flow, viscous-dominated flows; Navier-Stokes equation; dimensional analysis; internal and external flows, boundary layers, and lift and drag on objects.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: (1) be able to define basic terms, values and laws in the areas of fluids properties, statics, kinematics and dynamics of fluids; (2) be able to describe methods of implementing fluid mechanics laws and phenomena; (3) be able to practically apply tables and diagrams, and equations that define the associated laws; (4) be able to select engineering approach to problem solving based on the acquired physics and mathematical knowledge.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: The recommended reading list/references will be determined by course instructor.

title: Mechanical Design
description: This course covers the engineering design principles, machine design methods, design of machine components, and kinematics. Load analysis, design for manufacturing, reliability and human factors will also be introduced and reviewed.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: (1) understand mechanical engineering design process, particularly machine design theory and methodology; (2) develop critical thinking skills for design synthesis and analysis; (3) obtain the core knowledge in engineering and mechanical design.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: Richard G. Budynas. Shigley's Mechanical Engineering Design. New York, NY: McGraw-Hill Science/Engineering/Math: 2014, 10 edition.

title: Introduction to Control Systems
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR3406.
description: This course provides students with fundamental knowledge of control systems. It covers the following topics: mathematical modelling and linear approximation of engineering systems, Laplace transform, transfer function and block diagram representation, characteristics of feedback systems, performance specifications, Routh-Hurwitz stability criterion, root locus design, frequency response design and Nyquist criterion. The utilization of computer-aided analysis and design software is also included.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: (1) be able to to qualitatively and quantitatively ascertain the advantages and disadvantages of closed loop system; (2) be able to utilize various mathematical techniques in the modeling, stability analysis and performance evaluation of close loop system; (3) understand the needed trade-off in a design process; (4) understand the characteristics and analytical tools in different control design method; (5) be able to use the computation tools Matlab for analysis and design; (6) design a controller upon given a system and desired performance specifications; (7) be able to conduct assigned system and control experiments to verify predicted phenomenon.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: (1) Modern Control Systems, by R.C. Dorf and R.H. Bishop, 13rd Edition, Pearson Prentice Hall. (2) Feedback Control of Dynamic Systems, by G.F. Franklin, J.D. Powell, and A. Emami-Naeini, 7th Edition, Prentice Hall. (3) Modern Control Engineering, by K. Ogata, 5th Edition, Prentice Hall.

title: Introduction to Robotics
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR3408 or ELEG3103.
description: The course covers the basic and fundamentals to the study of robotic manipulators, including: classification of robots, robot sensors and actuators, coordinate frames and homogeneous transformations, Denavit-Hartenberg notation, forwards and inverse kinematics, Jacobians and statics, singularity and workspace analysis, and trajectory generation. The course includes a creative project component for students to apply robot manipulators for a new and innovative application. This requires the students to design a new application for robot manipulators that would be useful to the community and globally. By using the introduction to the state-of-the-art in robotics around the world, and fundamentals learnt in the course, the students have to innovatively design and present the idea as a mock start-up company project.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: (1) solve the forward and inverse kinematics problems in robot manipulators; (2) generate and analyse the Jacobian matrix, singularities and workspace in robot manipulators; (3) perform trajectory generation and motion planning in robot manipulators; (4) formulate the dynamics of robot manipulators; (5) understand the use and the significance of sensors and actuators in robotics; (6) apply fundamental knowledge of kinematics and motion planning on real robot hardware; (7) appreciate the significance of robotics to the society.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: (1) John J. Craig: Introduction to Robotics, 3rd Edition, Prentice Hall, 2005. (2) Bruno Siciliano et. Al.: Robotics: Modelling Planning and Control, Springer, 2009

title: Fundamentals of Computer-Aided Design
description: This course provides students with fundamentals of Computer Aided Design. It covers the following topics: elements of interactive graphics in CAD/CAM, mathematical bases and manipulation of curves and surfaces (parametric cubic curve, Bezier and NURBS curve, ruled surface, sweep surface, Coon's bilinear surface, Hermite surface, Bezier and NURBS surfaces), introduction to geometric and solid modeling (constructive solid geometry, boundary representation), and visualization for engineering simulation. Applications in design and manufacturing are also included.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: (1) have a basic understanding of how objects are manipulated in a 3D space; (2) understand the different types of curves and surfaces for modelling 3D objects; (3) learn the basic concept and the different approaches for geometric and solid modelling; (4) learn the popular techniques for visualizing 3D objects; (5) to be capable of developing simple graphics applications.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: (1) Vera B Anand, Computer Graphics and Geometric Modeling for Engineers, John Wiley & Son, Inc. 1993. (2) Edward Angel, Interactive Computer Graphics, A Top-Down Approach with OpenGL, Addison Wesley, 2000. (3) http://www.opengl.org/

title: Fundamentals of Machine Intelligence
description: This course provides students with fundamental knowledge of machine intelligence. It covers the following topics: data structures, sorting and searching, knowledge representation (state space, logical statements, rules, connectionism), discrete problem solving by state space search, deduction by resolution in predicate logic, inference by ruled-based systems, mappings by networks, and principles of learning. The application examples are also included.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: (1) be able to develop the concepts of organizing data properly according to the problem in hand, of solution space to any problem, of logical thinking, of using divide-and-conquer technique to solve problems, and of using systematic methodology to approach problems.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: (1) “Artificial Intelligence”, by Elaine Rich and Kevin Knight, 2nd Edition, 1991, McGraw-Hill. (2) “Artificial Intelligence: structures and strategies for complex problem solving”, by George F. Luger, 5th Edition, 2005, published by Addison Wesley. (3) “Date Structures Using C”, by A.M. Tenenbaum, Y. Langsam, and M.J. Augenstein, 1990, Prentice-Hall. (4) “Object-oriented programming in Common LISP: a programmer’s guide to CLOS”, by S.E. Keene and D. Gerson, published by Addison-Wesley, 1989. (5) “LISP”, by P.H. Winston and B.K.P. Horn, 3rd Edition, 1989, Addison-Wesley.

title: Engineering Design and Applications
description: The course is intended to enable students to learn the fundamentals of engineering design and how to carry out the design process. One (or several) engineering project(s)s for students to practice is (are) included with the following topics: engineering design process, innovation and design basics, CAD and CAE tools and applications, prototyping (mechanical workshop), prototyping (electronics workshop), quality and inspection.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: (1) understand the design and implementation of engineering design technologies to address specific engineering challenges during and after the course. (2) be skilled at communicating with appropriate software and media, including mathematical graphical representations (engineering 2D and 3D drawings), written reports and oral presentations for an assigned project. (3) understand the strategic aspects and processes of new product design by applying computer integrated manufacturing technology, such as rapid prototyping and 3D printing. (4) be capable of introducing the influences of technological, environmental, social and cultural considerations on design and manufacturing decisions. (5) be capable of performing evaluation and identification of the target markets and customers, strategic product features and benefits of the new designs and manufacturing methods.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: (1) Engineering Design: A Project-Based Introduction, by Clive L. Dym, Patrick Little, Elizabeth J. Orwin and R. Erik Spjut, 3rd edition, Wiley 2009 (2) Engineering Design, by Rudolph J. Eggert, Pearson Prentice Hall 2005.

title: Computer-integrated Manufacturing
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR4408.
description: This course provides students with a solid background in the fundamentals of computer-integrated manufacturing technology. It covers the following topics: concurrent engineering, computer-integrated manufacturing models and concepts, rapid prototyping, computer-aided manufacturing, control of manufacturing systems (numerical control and computer numerical control), programmable logic controller, computer aided process planning and manufacturing scheduling, and quality assurance. The hands-on experiments and projects are included.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: (1) understand the design and implementation of specific computer-integrated manufacturing technologies addressed during the course; (2) understand the strategic aspects and processes of new product design and manufacturing by applying computer integrated manufacturing technology;  (3) be able to skill at communicating with appropriate media, including mathematical graphical representations; (engineering drawings), written reports and oral presentations; (4) be able to introduce the influences of technological, environmental, social and cultural considerations on design and manufacturing decisions; (5) be able to identify the target markets and customers, strategic product features and benefits of the new design and manufacturing methods.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: The recommended reading list/references will be determined by course instructor.

title: Finite Element Modelling and Analysis
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR4410.
description: The purpose of this course is to learn the mathematical and computational method for finite element analysis. Students will learn the computational procedure, basic elements, shape functions and the method for imposing boundary conditions. The numerical implementation for finite element analysis will also be learned. Finite element analysis software will be used in project to solve engineering applications.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: (1) be able to apply knowledge of engineering mathematics and science, to the finite element modelling and analysis; (2) be able to design a component using finite element method to meet desired needs within constraints, such as safety, manufacturability and sustainability; (3) be able to formulate and solve engineering problems using finite element method; (4) be able to use the computer / IT tools relevant to the finite element method along with an understanding of their processes and limitations.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: (1) O. C. Zienkiewicz, The finite element method (6th Ed.), volume 1, Oxford; Burlington, MA: Elsevier Butterworth-Heinemann, 2005. (2) Alan J. Davies, The finite element method: a first approach, Oxford: Clarendon Press; New York: Oxford University Press, 1980. (3) Other recommended reading list/references to be determined by the course instructor.

title: Heat Transfer
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR4412.
description: This course will cover fundamental topics in heat transfer including physical origins of three heat transfer modes and their rate equations, heat diffusion equation, boundary and initial conditions, steady-state and transient conduction, numerical methods, boundary layer equation, external and internal forced convection, free convection, and thermal radiation.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: (1) correctly identify and understand relevant heat transfer physical phenomena by applying laws of thermodynamics and rate equations; (2) formulate problems mathematically in heat transfer applications; (3) solve the formulated heat transfer problems analytically and numerically.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: (1) Frank P. Incropera, David P. Dewitt, Theodore L. Bergman, and Adrienne S. Lavine, Foundations of Heat Transfer, 6th Ed., International Student Version, John Wiley & Sons, Inc. (2) Other recommended reading list/references to be determined by the course instructor.

title: Mechatronic Systems
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR4414.
description: Mechatronics is at the intersection of mechanical, electronic, control, and software engineering. This course will cover the technologies involved in developing and designing intelligent electro-mechanical systems. Specific topics include physical system modelling and analysis, measurement and manipulation principles, sensors, actuators, data acquisition and conversion, microcontrollers and interface, control system design and tuning. The course includes a significant lab component with a course project in mechatronics system design. Students will involve in hands-on programming project to reinforce the basic principles developed in lectures as well as develop control algorithm implementation skillsets.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: (1) analyze the principles of actuators, sensors, as well as electronics and hardware components on the integration and application of mechatronic systems;  (2) design, build, program and troubleshoot mechatronic systems; (3) competent to work as individuals and as members of a small team to communicate the results in a professional manner.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: Introduction to Mechatronics and Measurement Systems, 2nd edition by D. Alciatore and M. Histand McGraw-Hill, 2003.

title: Modern Control Systems Analysis and Design
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR4416.
description: This course provides students with the knowledge of modern control systems analysis and design. It covers the following topics: continuous and discrete domain state space representations (including transition matrix, stability, controllability and observability, pole placement control, state estimator), emulation design, and discrete design. Case studies are also included.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: (1) be able to derive a state-space model for a given physical system; (2) be able to perform stability analysis and computer simulation of time responses of the model; (3) be able to perform various feedback controller design methods such as pole placement, observer design, feedforward design, internal model design, LQR method for fulfilling different design specifications; (4) be able to analyze and design a discrete-time control system in both frequency domain and time domain.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: (1) Gene F. Franklin, et al., Feedback Control of Dynamic Systems, 6th Ed., Prentice Hall, 2010. (2) Katsuhiko Ogata, Modern Control Engineering, 4th Ed., Prentice Hall, Inc., 2002. (3) Richard C. Dorf and Robert H. Bishop, Modern Control Systems, 9th Ed., Addison Wesley, 2001. (4) Gene F. Franklin, et al, Digital Control of Dynamic Systems, 3rd Ed., Addison Wesley Publishing Co., 1997.

title: Virtual Reality Systems and Applications
description: This course provides students with knowledge of virtual reality systems and applications. It covers the following topics: introduction of virtual reality in engineering applications, sensors and actuators, principle and mechanism of VR equipment, model representation in VR, computational physics in virtual reality, real-time rendering, and virtual prototyping. Applications in engineering analysis and simulation are also included.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: (1) understand the basic components in the kernel of a VR system, and be able to specify three dimensional object shapes and movement of objects in mathematical terms; (2) be able to use appropriate programming tools for developing virtual reality applications; (3) be able to use standard input and output devices in virtual reality applications; (4) be able to develop simple virtual reality applications.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: (1) M. Slater, A. Steed, Y. Chrysanthou, Computer Graphics and Virtual Environments, Addison Wesley, 2002. (2) G. Burdea, P. Coiffet, Virtual Reality Technology, John Wiley, 2003. (3) J. Vince, Virtual Reality Systems, Addison Wesley, 1995.

title: Engineering Optimization
requirements: Not for students who have taken ESTR4418.
description: The course will introduce basic concepts of engineering optimization methods as applied to engineering problems. The theory and application of optimization techniques will be presented, including unconstrained and constrained optimization, Lagrange multiplier, necessary and sufficient conditions for optimality and dynamical programming.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: (1) be able to formulate various engineering design problems into optimization problems;  (2) be able to solve various optimization problems including both linear and nonlinear programming, both analytic and numeric methods, and both constrained and unconstrained problems;  (3) be able to apply various optimization approaches to design problems encompassing mechanical engineering, electrical engineering, and manufacturing engineering.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: Engineering Optimization – Theory and Practice (4th Edition), S. S. Rao © 2009 John Wiley & Sons, Inc.

title: Introduction to Combustion
requirements: Pre-requisite: MAEG2030/ESTR2402 and MAEG3030.;Not for students who have taken ESTR4420.
description: Combustion and its control are essential to our daily life and more than 80% of the energy used nowadays is from combustion sources. This course starts with the basic principles that govern combustion phenomena such as conservation of mass, the first and second laws of thermodynamics, and the momentum principle. Then students will learn the new applications of these basic principles to account for the chemical transformations. We will discuss the basic concepts of chemical kinetics and the forms of reaction rate laws that apply in combustion processes, as well as mass transport phenomena. These laws will be applied to a variety of combustion phenomena, including spontaneous ignition of combustible mixtures, pollutant formation, internal combustion engine and fire safety.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: (1) be able to use the principles of thermochemistry, fluid dynamics, and chemical kinetics to understand the basic combustion process; (2) be able to calculate flame temperature for an idealized fuel-air mixture; (3) be able to understand qualitatively how non-ideal factors affect flame temperature; (4) be able to understand the difference between the basic types of internal combustion engines; (5) be able to analyze an ideal engine cycle using thermodynamic diagrams and analyze the system performance of ideal Otto, Diesel and Brayton thermodynamic cycles; (6) be able to analyze how CO, NO, unburned hydrocarbons and soot emissions are formed in engines and solutions to minimize them.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: (1) Stephen Turns, “An Introduction to Combustion: Concepts and Applications: 3rd Edition”, Jan 2011, McGraw-Hill Companies,Inc. (ISBN: 0073380199) (2) John B. Heywood, “Internal Combustion Engine Fundamentals”, April 1988, McGraw-Hill Companies,Inc. (ISBN: 007028637X) (3) Sara McAllister, Jyh-Yuan Chen, A. Carlos Fernandez-Pello, “Fundamentals of Combustion Processes”, April 2011, Springer-Verlag New York, LLC. (ISBN: 1441979425)

title: Final Year Project I
description: The course is designed to provide students with an opportunity to carry out, under the supervision of an academic staff, an independent project with research elements in engineering.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: (1) be able to identify and have a basic understanding of the literature related to the project topic; (2) be able to define and complete a project that utilizes results in the literature; (3) be able to perform a critical review of the project; (4) develop technical writing skills.
syllabus: The course includes, but is not limited to, the following elements: literature review, modelling, system design and implementation, project evaluation.
required_readings: Literature review materials will be recommended by the project supervisor.

title: Final Year Project II
requirements: Pre-requisite: MAEG4998.
description: The course is designed to provide students with an opportunity to carry out, under the supervision of an academic staff, an independent project with research elements in engineering.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: (1) be able to identify and have a basic understanding of the literature related to the project topic; (2) be able to define and complete a project that utilizes results in the literature; (3) be able to perform a critical review of the project; (4) develop technical writing skills.
syllabus: The course includes, but is not limited to, the following elements: literature review, modelling, system design and implementation, project evaluation.
required_readings: Literature review materials will be recommended by the project supervisor.

title: Geometric Computing for Design and Manufacturing
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Mechanical and Automation Engineering; or For students in MSc Mechanical and Automation Engineering; or For students in UG Mechanical and Automation Engineering;Pre-requisite: MAEG3070 (for UG students only)
description: Geometric computing tools have been widely used in modern product design and realization, such as all kinds of Computer-Aided Design (CAD), Computer-Aided Manufacturing (CAM) and Computer-Aided Engineering (CAE) software systems. However, the capability of simply using these CAD, CAM and CAE software systems is not sufficient for future products design and manufacturing. This course aims to help students in understanding the principles of geometric computing behind CAD, CAM and CAE systems, and provides students with deep understanding of computational techniques and practical experience in developing novel computational design and manufacturing applications.

title: Computational Intelligence
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Mechanical and Automation Engineering or MSc Mechanical and Automation Engineering or UG Mechanical and Automation Engineering;Not for students who have taken MAEG5735
description: This course teaches concepts, models, methods, and applications of computational intelligence. Topics include neural networks, support vector machines, fuzzy systems, simulated annealing, genetic algorithms, and their applications to control, robotics, automation, manufacturing, and transportation.

title: Nonlinear Control Systems
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Mechanical and Automation Engineering; or For students in MSc Mechanical and Automation Engineering; or For students in UG Mechanical and Automation Engineering
description: This course consists of two parts. The first part is analysis of nonlinear systems, which includes state space description of nonlinear control systems, phase plane analysis of second order dynamic systems, Lyapunov ‘s stability theory such as Lyapunov’s first method, second method, Barbalat’s lemma, and total stability. The second part is design of nonlinear control systems, which includes Jacobian linearization, feedback linearization, sliding mode control, and backstepping method.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: (1) identify peculiar nonlinear phenomena such as chaos, bifurcation, limit cycles, etc.;  (2) use classical nonlinear analysis tools such as the phase plane method and Poincare theory to study two dimensional systems; (3) master advanced Lyaponov theory to analyze the stability property of both autonomous and non-autonomous nonlinear systems; (4) select and apply some modern nonlinear control analysis and design methods such as backstepping method, feedback linearization method, and sliding mode method to design nonlinear control laws for nonlinear control systems.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: 1. J.J. Slotine and W. Li, Applied Nonlinear Control, Prentice Hall Englewood Cliffs, 1991. 2. A. Isidori, Nonlinear Control Systems, third edition, 1995, Springer-Verlag. 3. Hasssan K. Khalil, Nonlinear Systems, second edition, 1996, Prentice-Hall. 4. Gene F. Franklin, et al, Feedback Control of Dynamic Systems, third edition, Addison Wesley Publishing Co., 1994. 5. Richard C. Dorf and Robert H. Bishop, Modern Control Systems, 7th edition, Addison-Wesley, 1995.

title: Smart Materials and Structures
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Mechanical and Automation Engineering; or For students in MSc Mechanical and Automation Engineering; or For students in UG Mechanical and Automation Engineering;Not for students who have taken MAEG5760
description: The contents of this course include overview of smart materials technology, characteristics of smart materials such as piezoelectric materials, magnetorheological fluids, and shape memory alloys. It covers smart actuators and sensors; structural modelling and design; dynamics and control for smart structures; integrated system analysis; and applications in biomedical devices, precision machinery, transportation, and buildings.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: (1) apply knowledge of engineering mathematics and science, to the subject of smart materials and structures; (2) design devices and/or systems using smart materials; (3) identify, formulate, and solve problems using smart materials technologies; (4) use the modern engineering tools for the subject of smart materials and structures.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: (1) Smart Materials and Structures, Institute of Physics (2) Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures, Sage Publications (3) Smart Structures Theory, by I. Chopra and J. Sirohi, Cambridge University Press, 2013 (4) Engineering Analysis of Smart Material Systems, by D. J. Leo, John Wiley & Sons, Inc., 2007 (5) Adaptronics and Smart Structures: Basics, Materials, Design, and Applications, by H. Janocha (ed.), Springer-Verlag, 2nd edition, 2007 (6) Adaptive Structures: Dynamics and Control, by R. L. Clark, W. R. Saunders, and G. P. Gibbs, John Wiley & Sons, Inc., 1998

title: Topics in Robotics
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Mechanical and Automation Engineering; or For students in MSc Mechanical and Automation Engineering; or For students in UG Mechanical and Automation Engineering
description: This course aims to teach students a range of classical and state-of-the-art topics through a series of examples. The focus will be on how different fundamental topics, such as linear and non-linear control, optimization, path planning, visual servo control, robot kinematics and dynamics, and machine learning, are applied through practical applications within robotics. Different application scenarios that may be used to show different fundamental topics include: mobile manipulation, bio-inspired and humanoid robots, robotic walking, rehabilitation robotics, medical and surgical robots, cable-driven robots, and autonomous ground, water and aerial vehicles.

title: Quantum Control and Quantum Information
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Mechanical and Automation Engineering; or For students in MSc Mechanical and Automation Engineering; or For students in UG Mechanical and Automation Engineering
description: The field of quantum information science includes quantum control and quantum information. It is a new area of inter-disciplinary research involving physicists, computer scientists, mathematicians and engineers. The course is an introduction to this rapidly expanding field. It covers basic quantum mechanics including quantum entanglement and quantum measurement; the modeling and control of quantum mechanical systems; quantum error correction; quantum communication and quantum information theory.

title: Nanomaterials and Nanotechnology: Fundamentals and Applications
requirements: For students in MSc/MPhil-PhD/UG Mechanical and Automation Engineering; or UG Energy and Environmental Engineering;Pre-requisite (for UG students only): [EEEN/ENER3030 or ESTR3402 (with grade B or above)] or [with the consent of the course instructor]
description: This course provides both fundamental knowledge of nanomaterials and nanotechnology and advanced topics related to applications. These topics cover basic principles, which include the scaling law, the surface science for nanomaterials, observation and characterization tools for nanomaterials, the nanofabrication techniques, building blocks for nanodevices and systems, etc. In the second half of this course, advanced topics on applying nanomaterials and nanotechnology for applications in mechanical engineering, energy engineering and biomedical engineering will be covered.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: (1) understand fundamental concepts of nanotechnology and nanomaterials, including the scaling law, the surface science for nanomaterials, observation and characterization tools; (2) understand the design principle and building blocks for nanodevices and systems; (3) have an overall view of biomimetics and bio-inspired designs at small scales, and understand the fundamental challenges for locomotion and manipulation at micro-/nanoscales; (4) understand material design principles of energy storage and conversion devices, solar energy harvesting devices and thermoelectric generators; (5) propose technical solutions using nanomaterials and nanotechnology to tackle given technical challenge in biomedicine and energy applications.  This course contributes to the following EEEN / MAEG Programme Learning Outcomes:  (1) E1: Acquired basic knowledge related to energy and environmental engineering, including physics, mathematics, thermodynamics, energy technologies, power systems, environmental economics, building control and assessment, air pollution, etc. (K,S);  (2) E5: Acquired the ability to identify, formulate and solve real-life engineering problems and tradeoffs related to energy system and optimization, environmental monitoring and control, and green building technologies (K,S); (3) E7: Developed proficiency in technical communication (both oral and written) (S); (4) M1: An ability to apply knowledge of engineering sciences and mathematics to the discipline of mechanical and automation engineering;  (5) M5: An ability to identify, formulate, and solve engineering problems; (6) M7: An ability to communicate effectively.  K = Knowledge outcomes; S = Skills outcomes; V = Values and attitude outcomes.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.

title: Computational Mechanics
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Mechanical and Automation Engineering; or For students in MSc Mechanical and Automation Engineering; or For students in UG Mechanical and Automation Engineering
description: Mechanics is the foundation of many emerging research and engineering topics. With the rapid advancement in computing power, numerical methods are preferred to solve differential equations governing the physical process. It opens a whole new domain in industrial design, manufacturing process analysis, material behaviour prediction, etc. This course covers theoretical fundamentals in computational mechanics, including continuum mechanics, finite element methods, and computational plasticity. In addition, the course will also introduce practical skills to applying computational mechanics in research, including multi-physics simulation and advanced finite element simulation techniques.

title: Materials Characterization Techniques
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD/MSc/UG Mechanical and Automation Engineering; or UG Energy and Environmental Engineering;Pre-requisite: EEEN/ENER3030 or ESTR3402 for UG students only (with grade B or above)
description: This course focuses on a suite of materials characterization techniques that are useful in energy and environmental sciences. The main targets of these techniques include functional materials that are used in energy and environmental applications as well as solid, liquid, and gas samples that are involved in energy production and conversion, and pollution monitoring and control. The techniques include mass spectrometry (MS), gas chromatography (GC), high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC), nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), infrared (IR) spectroscopy, Raman spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), electron microscopy, and X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectroscopy. Students will receive lectures on the theory and operation principle of each technique as well as its limitations, and obtain hands-on experience with some of the techniques in supplemental lab sessions.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: (1) understand operation principles and limitations of a suite of materials characterization techniques that are useful in energy and environmental sciences; (2) gain hands-on experience with some of the techniques; (3) develop an ability to choose suitable characterization techniques for their research needs.  This course contributes to the following EEEN / MAEG Programme Learning Outcomes:  (1) E1: Acquired basic knowledge related to energy and environmental engineering, including physics, mathematics, thermodynamics, energy technologies, power systems, environmental economics, building control and assessment, air pollution, etc. (K,S);  (2) E2: Acquired the ability to design and conduct experimental studies and computational analysis, as well as to analyze and interpret the data obtained (K,S); (3) E5: Acquired the ability to identify, formulate and solve real-life engineering problems and tradeoffs related to energy system and optimization, environmental monitoring and control, and green building technologies (K,S); (4) E11: Acquired the ability to use the techniques, skills and tools to practice in the energy and environmental engineering discipline and be aware of entrepreneur opportunities (K,S);  (5) M1: An ability to apply knowledge of engineering sciences and mathematics to the discipline of mechanical and automation engineering; (6) M2: An ability to design and conduct experiments, as well as to analyze and interpret data; (7) M5: An ability to identify, formulate, and solve engineering problems; (8) M11: An ability to use the techniques, skills and tools to practice in the mechanical and automation engineering discipline.  K = Knowledge outcomes; S = Skills outcomes; V = Values and attitude outcomes.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: (1) Chapter 4, "Concepts of modern catalysis and kinetics" by I. Chorkendorff and J.W. Niemantsverdriet, Weinheim: Wiley-VCH, 2007.

title: Design for Additive Manufacturing
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Mechanical and Automation Engineering; or For students in MSc Mechanical and Automation Engineering; or For students in UG Mechanical and Automation Engineering - Major
description: This course provides a theoretical and practical guidance on how to design parts to gain the maximum benefit from what additive manufacturing (AM) can offer. It begins by describing the main AM technologies and their respective advantages and disadvantages. It then examines strategic considerations in the context of designing for additive manufacturing (DfAM), such as designing to avoid anisotropy, designing to minimize print time, and post-processing, before discussing the economics of AM. The course then focuses on computational tools for design analysis and the optimization of AM parts, part consolidation, and tooling applications. Both designing for polymer AM and metal AM and its corresponding design guidelines will be provided. The main benefit of the course is its combined theoretical and practical approach, which provides directly applicable, “hands-on” information and insights to help students adopt AM in their daily practice.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes:(1) explain the topological optimization algorithms used in existing CAD/CAE systems;(2) apply mathematical formulations in their programming implementation for topological optimization;(3) understand and apply different design rules for polymer and metal Additive Manufacturing;(4) understand advantages and disadvantages of different Additive Manufacturing Technologies and corresponding design constraints.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
required_readings: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: (1) Olaf Diegel, A Practical Guide to Design for Additive Manufacturing, Springer, 2019(2) M.P. Bendsoe, Topological Optimization. Theory, Methods and Applications, Springer, 2004(3) Topology Optimization in Engineering Structure Design, ISTE-Elsevier, 2017

title: Computer Aided Design and Manufacturing
requirements: For students in MSc Mechanical and Automation Engineering;Not for students who have taken MAEG5030
description: This course focuses on the technologies for the modeling and visualization of 3D objects. This includes topics on the transformation of objects and coordinate systems. Techniques for the representation of free form curves and surfaces including parametric cubic, Bezier, B-spline, and NURBS will be covered. Techniques for modeling trimmed surface will also be studied. The basic theory of solid modeling and representation schemes will be covered. The Constructive Solid Geometry and the Boundary Representation scheme will be studied. The basic concept for the generation of machining tool paths will be covered. There will also be an introduction to feature based design.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: 1. Able to identify geometric functions of computer-aided design and manufacturing; 2. Able to apply engineering mathematics knowledge to conduct analysis for computer-aided design and manufacturing; 3. Competent to identify the influences of modern computing techniques on the development of advanced computer-aided design and manufacturing; and 4. Skilled at computer programming for computer-aided design and manufacturing.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: 1. VeraB.Anand,ComputerGraphicsandGeometricModelingforEngineers,JohnWiley,1993. 2. HoffmannCM,GeometricandSolidModeling,MorganKaufmann,1989. 3. http://www.opengl.org

title: Computer Interface and Simulation
requirements: For students in MSc Mechanical and Automation Engineering
description: This course will be offered to cover the knowledge of computer interface, including sensor, actuators, haptics, and human-computer interaction methods. To support the usage of human-computer interface, methods for 3D object modeling, deformation and simulation will be taught to make an integrated interaction and simulation system.

title: Computer Vision in Practice
requirements: For students in MSc Mechanical and Automation Engineering
description: This course provides students with theoretical backgrounds of computer vision. It will cover the following topics: imaging models; segmentation; pose estimation by visual means; 3D shape estimation by stereo vision; camera and stereo calibration; and motion tracking. A wide variety of case studies and practical applications in engineering are also included.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: 1. Able to synthesize image and video observations in a camera from 3-D shape, motion, camera position, and camera settings; 2. Able to calibrate imaging system; 3. Understand the process of retrieving 3-D shapes and motions from image data using stereo vision, visual motion, and other vision cues; and 4. Able to relate typical engineering problems that require access to 3-D, to particular vision cues and the corresponding setups of the imaging system.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
required_readings: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: The details will be provided by the course instructor.

title: Control and Industrial Automation
requirements: For students in MSc Mechanical and Automation Engineering;Not for students who have taken ENGG5403
description: This course is designed to equip students with the knowledge of modern control systems analysis and design, and skills of control theory for practical applications of industrial automation systems. It will cover the following topics: state space representation, realizability, stability, controllability, observability; linear control design methods including pole placement, observer, asymptotic tracking and disturbance rejection, internal model design, and feedforward design; introduction to nonlinear systems. Various examples, e.g., robot control, satellite's attitude control and servomechanism are included.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: 1. Able to derive a state-space model for a given physical system; 2. Able to perform stability analysis and computer simulation of time responses of the model; and 3. Able to perform feedback controller design for fulfilling a given specification.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: 1. Feedback control of dynamic systems, 6ed, Gene F. Franklin, Prentice Hall, 2012 2. Applied Nonlinear Control, J.J. Slotine and W. Li, Prentice Hall Englewood Cliffs, 1991

title: Applied Computational Intelligence
requirements: For students in MSc Mechanical and Automation Engineering;Not for students who have taken MAEG5060
description: This course applies computationally intelligent algorithms to solve mechanical and automation problems. It consists of the following topics: various areas of emerging technologies of computationally intelligent systems; introduction and review of neural networks; support vector machines; fuzzy systems; simulated annealing, and genetic algorithms; the applications of intelligent systems to control, robotics, automation, manufacturing, and transportation systems.

title: Measurement and Instrumentation
requirements: For students in MSc Mechanical and Automation Engineering
description: This course is intended to provide basic concepts and methods to interface electro-mechanical parts and sensors to computers. It covers the following topics: analogue and digital circuitry; design of linear circuits with ICs and Op-amps; design of low-noise circuits.

title: Microelectromechanical Systems Technology and Applications
requirements: For students in MSc Mechanical and Automation Engineering;Not for students who have taken ENGG5404
description: This course covers the general introduction to micro-systems including integrated circuits, micromachine design, and microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) fabrication techniques. The second part of the course includes the scaling law, operational principles, design and analysis of microscale sensors and actuators, and the applications of micro sensors and actuators in robotic, biomedical, aerospace, and manufacturing industries.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: 1. Understand state-of-the-art technologies for fabricating micro- and nano-scale structures, machines, and systems; 2. Understand the principles that govern the designs of micro/nano sensors and actuators; and 3. Apply applications of MEMS and Nanotechnology in advanced research projects and commercial products.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: 1. Senturia, Stephen D. Microsystem Design. New York, NY: Springer, 2004. ISBN: 9780792372462. 2. Campbell, Stephen A. title: Robotics
requirements: For students in MSc Mechanical and Automation Engineering;Not for students who have taken MAEG5090 or ENGG5402
description: This course will first give an introduction to robotics and its applications in industries and services; and then teach fundamentals in robotics including kinematics and dynamics of robot manipulators, sensors and actuators, motion control, and machine intelligence. Finally, examples of medical robotics and service robotics will be introduced.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: 1. Understand forward and inverse kinematics of robot manipulator; 2. Understand fundamental concepts in robot control; and 3. Understand robot sensors, actuators and basics in robot programming.

title: Energy and Environment
requirements: For students in MSc Mechanical and Automation Engineering
description: This course will discuss the global energy consumption and supply, thermodynamic principles of energy conversion and efficiency, fossil fuel usage, operation of nuclear power plant, emerging technologies utilizing renewable energy sources, energy harvesting and storage technologies, environmental impacts, energy systems management and government policy.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: 1. To understand the principles of power generation and various energy sources. 2. To understand the important issues of energy supply, utilization, and sustainability. 3. To be aware of the impacts of energy consumption to the environment, for example, climate change and global warming.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
recommended_readings: 1. Fundamentals of renewable energy processes, 2ed

title: Railway Engineering and Systems
requirements: For students in MSc Mechanical and Automation Engineering
description: The course is designed to allow the post-graduate students to be kept abreast of the various key engineering systems and components for a modern railway. This includes operations and key components of modern railway systems; core systems including rolling stock, signaling, communication, control, AFC, traction power systems; project management; system Integration including System V&V process, project lifecycle modeling, system assurance and EMC management; railway development planning; and railway capacity modeling.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should have achieved the following outcomes: 1. To understand the modern railway transportation technologies and engineering considerations; 2. To appreciate train and railway systems design and technologies, and their impact to the environment; 3. To understand the railway development planning and railway capacity modeling; and 4. To understand railway operation and maintenance, safety concerns and risk management.

title: Precision Machine Design and Vibration Control
requirements: For students in MSc Mechanical and Automation Engineering
description: This course is designed to address the challenges of modern precision and high speed automation machinery design technology. It covers design methods, selection on components and systems, precision measurement and vibration control with industrial practical knowledge.
outcome: After completing this course, the student should understand the precision machine design methods and applications domain knowledge. The course develops professional engineering competence that enable students to have career opportunities to join relevant industries.

title: M.Sc. Project
requirements: For students in MSc Mechanical and Automation Engineering
description: In this course, each student will perform research on a topic related to research areas in the Department of Mechanical and Automation Engineering. The project will be supervised by faculty members in the MAE department. At the end of the project, the student is required to submit a written report and give an oral presentation for the assessment of performance.
outcome: Upon the completion of the course, students should have achieved the following course learning outcomes: 1. A good understanding on the fundamental knowledge and latest development of the selected research area; 2. The ability to conduct research in the selected research area and adequate problem solving skills; 3. Good communication skills in terms of both written report and oral presentation.
syllabus: In this course, each student will perform research on a topic related to research areas in the MAE department under the supervision of faculty members. No class will be arranged. The student will meet with the supervisor regularly to discuss the research progress. At the end of the project, the student is required to submit a written report and give an oral presentation for the assessment of performance.
recommended_readings: Reading materials will be provided by each supervisor according to research topics.

title: Thesis Research
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Mechanical and Automation Engineering
description: In this course, a student is required to meet with his/her supervisor regularly who provides necessary guidance and supervision to write up a thesis and monitors the student's academic progress.
outcome: Under the regular supervision of the thesis advisor, the student learns how to formulate a research question in an area of his/her interest, articulate the long-term goals and shorter-term objectives of his/her research, critically review the background literatures, plan and conduct the research activities, become competent in the underpinning knowledge and skills, analyze, present and discuss the results thoroughly, and draw appropriate conclusions based on the findings. The student is expected to mature as a more independent researcher as he/she progresses in his/her research study.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.

description: In this course, a student is required to meet with his/her supervisor regularly who provides necessary guidance and supervision to write up a thesis and monitors the student's academic progress.
outcome: Under the regular supervision of the thesis advisor, the student learns how to formulate a research question in an area of his/her interest, articulate the long-term goals and shorter-term objectives of his/her research, critically review the background literatures, plan and conduct the research activities, become competent in the underpinning knowledge and skills, analyze, present and discuss the results thoroughly, and draw appropriate conclusions based on the findings. The student is expected to mature as a more independent researcher as he/she progresses in his/her research study.
syllabus: The details will be provided by the course instructor.
